text:
I went to see her. I don’t know why I did. I am a worthless person, Dounia.  
  
‘You might be worthless, but you are ready to face pain! Right?’  
‘Yes, I am going. Right now. I thought about drowning myself to escape the shame, but when I looked at the water, I realized that if I thought I was strong, I shouldn’t be afraid of disgrace,’ he said quickly. ‘It’s pride, Dounia.’  
‘Pride, Rodya.’  
  
There was a spark in his dull eyes; he seemed happy to think he still had some pride.  
‘You don’t think I was just scared of the water, do you?’ he asked, looking at her with a strange smile.  
‘Oh, Rodya, stop!’ Dounia said sadly.  
  
They sat in silence for two minutes. He stared at the floor while Dounia stood at the other end of the table, looking at him with worry. Suddenly, he stood up.  
‘It’s late, I need to go! I’m going to turn myself in. But I don’t know why I’m doing it.’  
  
Tears rolled down her cheeks.  
‘You’re crying, sister, but can you hold out your hand to me?’  
‘Did you doubt it?’  
She hugged him tightly.  
‘Aren’t you partly paying for your crime by facing the pain?’ she said, holding him close and kissing him.  
‘Crime? What crime?’ he shouted in anger. ‘That I killed a disgusting old woman who was a pawnbroker?’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov grapples with his feelings of contemptibility and pride as he prepares to face the consequences of his actions.
